title: 111_hr6256
content:
The Act titled "Strengthening FHA Through Shared Equity Homeownership Act of 2010" includes a Shared Equity Pilot Program. The Shared Equity Pilot Program under the "Strengthening FHA Through Shared Equity Homeownership Act of 2010" aims to analyze the effectiveness of providing FHA mortgage insurance for 1- to 4-family residences financed through shared equity arrangements with private investors. The Shared Equity Pilot Program allows private investors to invest in equity funds for residences, sharing ownership. The Secretary establishes eligibility requirements for entities to participate and selects participants within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will select up to 8 individuals and entities for the pilot program based on criteria including methodology for deploying equity sharing capital, targeted markets, legal agreements, and expected revenue levels. The pilot program requires the mortgagor to occupy the residence as their primary home, make a downpayment of at least 3.5% of the appraised value, maintain a minimum ownership of 60% in the shared equity arrangement, and pay insurance premiums as specified. (g) The Secretary will collect annual premium payments on insured mortgages under the pilot program based on the annual premium charged under the National Housing Act, adjusted for reduced risk. 
(h) Requirements will be established to ensure the mortgagor maintains occupancy rights in the property. Transactional documentation will address the rights and responsibilities of both the mortgagor and shared equity investor. 
(i) The Secretary will ensure geographic diversity in carrying out the pilot program. The Secretary will carry out a pilot program in multiple regional mortgage markets in the United States with a limit of $25,000,000 for equity sharing capital investments per eligible entity. The program must be implemented within a two-year period, and the Secretary has the authority to waive certain requirements except for those related to fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards. The Secretary will monitor and report on the pilot program, investors, and shared equity arrangements to determine effectiveness. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress analyzing the pilot program's effectiveness and recommending expansion within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will analyze the pilot program's effectiveness and recommend expansion within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
